isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - HEHR POWER SYSTEMS/POWERLINE ALTERNATORS USED ON EMERGENCY VEHICLES - TESTING AND ANALYSIS OF CHARGING SYSTEM - OPTIMIZING THE CHARGING SYSTEM

svcproc.title: OPTIMIZING THE CHARGING SYSTEM
svcproc.para: If the discharge current is 15 amps or less, you may be able to optimize the system to correct the problem.

step1.para: Increase alternator speed by increasing engine idle speed, pulley ratio or both. Increasing the engine idle from 700 RPM to 750 RPM will improve the alternator output by 15 to 20 amps Decreasing the size of the alternator pulley by .2 inch can increase output by 5 to 15 amps at 700 RPM.
Make sure the alternator has a remote sense (direct to battery)! This will improve system voltage by 0.2 volts and give 10% more current at full field.

note.para: Never run the 10-120 regulator open sense on an emergency vehicle! This creates a negative temperature coefficient that will drop system voltage by 1 Volt when hot.

step1.para: Upgrade the battery cables if they are too small. There should be less than 0.5 volt drop between the alternator POS terminal and the battery POS terminal. The voltage drop between the alternator NEG. terminal and the NEG. battery terminal should be less than 0.2 volt during full load conditions. A 2 AWG cable for runs up to 5 feet, a 0 AWG cable for 5 to 10 feet runs, and a 2/0 AWG cable for runs from 10 to 15 feet is recommended.

svcproc.para: Add a separate ground cable for systems with a chassis ground.
